text: When we first got to the restaurant it was extremely crowded due to happy hour. The drinks were great and service at the bar was quick, but getting a table proved really difficult. We waited for almost an hour and a half to be seated. At the bar we ordered the soft tacos which were extremely delicious. All the ingredients tasted extremely fresh, which created a unique twist to the normal Tex Mex cuisine one would expect. The rice was absolutely to die for! Will definitely make an effort to go back and try brunch.

2 stars but only because I'm still reeling from my tequila sunset. I've been here twice now & have yet to have a satisfactory review. The first time, I ordered the pork nachos & found myself munching on bones. Disgusting. Rather than take them off our bill, they gave us drink coupons for a future visit. Umm. I wasn't impressed the first time, an now you want me to come back? By the way, the margaritas were weak.  So I ended up coming back over a year later for a work brunch thing. The service was mediocre at best, granted we had a fairly large party - but with a reservation - so they could have been prepared. Hubbo ordered a breakfast margarita & it was horrible so he traded it in for a tap beer. I ordered smoked enchiladas. It was about 80% beans & 20% two of the smallest enchiladas I've ever had. Again, to make up for service, waitress brought by  EXPIRED drink coupons. Way to win me over El Dorado...

Eldorado is perhaps my favorite brunch place in Madison. In general, I'm a big fan of the go with a few other food-loving people, order as many items as you think you can handle, and try them all. This feels like the only tactic to use at Eldorado, because it's all soooo good. First, a little booze: Eldorado has a slate of flavorful Bloody Mary-like drinks that you can order with chili infused vodka or tequila. If you want a kick in the morning, go that route. If you want something strong and sweet, I'd recommend the tequila sunrise. Yum.  For savory options: If you're looking for something classically Tex-Mex, you can't go wrong with the chilaquiles. Fried tortillas, eggs, salsa, beans, cheese, it's all there. If you want something more Tex and less Mex, the Texas Two Step is a good (and filling) choice. One huge biscuit split in half with one side covered in a sausage patty and gravy and the other paired with eggs and thick, smoky bacon. The Two Step will make you want to nap for a while, but you will enjoy every bite.  As for sweets: Let's just say this right away: Eldorado's French toast is probably the best in the city. Not overly eggy, not soggy. It's sweet and covered in cinnamon and it's CRUNCHY! They use a secret ingredient (which I won't spoil here, but ask the right waitperson and they'll clue you in) to keep the French toast interesting. It's fantastic. Aside from that, their blue corn flapjack is a star. Served with red chili butter and maple syrup, it is fluffy and flavorful.  Overall, Eldorado really excels at doing brunch. Just be prepared to feel stuffed and maybe plan in advance to include a siesta in your day.

Eldorado is consistently great! The margaritas are hands-down the best in Madison.  The salsa is really good too - wish they would jar it.  The steak with the collard greens and blue cheese butter is amazing.  Last time I tried the corn quesadilla.  This is no ordinary quesadilla - I've been thinking about it ever since I had it.  Service is great.  I've been eating here for years and will continue to come back!

Two words: Rip. Off.   Everything here is overpriced in an otherwise reasonably priced city. $12 for only two chorizo tacos?! You must be kidding. They were good, but not worth the price. I realize I've got it good living in a city where there are Mexicans, but there is simply no reason to gouge customers for mediocre food. The standard sides are black beans and rice. The black beans were bland, the rice forgettable. I substituted the collard greens and corn cakes, which were also unimpressive, unless you just want straight-up collard greens cooked a bit on the flattop with nothing else added. What's the matter Eldorado Grill? Afraid dairy-loving Sconnies can't stand the taste of Flavor?   I had a tasty, spicy tequila drink backed up with a bottle of Tecate, so it wasn't a complete loss...

Hadn't been to Eldorado in a while, mostly because I lumped it in with its FoodFight brethren in the category of "Generally meh."  I was totally wrong.   While there's still the FoodFight hallmark of style over substance, our entrees were interesting and excellent. Our server was outstanding with very friendly explanations, attentive refills of things and an overall nice pacing.  Very nicely done, y'all!
Awesome atmosphere, great drinks but when it come to food.. let's just say Meh is the best I can say. Sorry I don't buy into free chips and salsa. Disclaimer we went their for brunch(not dinner)

No free chips and salsa? You cannot brand yourself as Tex-Mex without this. It's a rite of passage. Queso? That's not queso. Don't order it. It's melted cheese on chips. No frozen margaritas? What nonsense is that? At least it's tasty. Those three things make this restaurant a no-go for Tex-Mex authenticity.  Those little mishaps aside, El Dorado has some charm. As far as Tex-Mex (food) in Madison goes, this place is pretty solid. I wouldn't say it's great, but I understand the appeal. The food is tasty, but as a native Texan, I crave chips and salsa, queso, and frozen margaritas. Step your game up, El Dorado.  As for the food, I had the spinach mushroom enchiladas, and they were delicious. The ingredients are fresh and well-cooked, and the presentation is spot-on. The margaritas were also tasty, but too many things threw me off about the restaurant for it to be one of my favorites in Madison.  Overall, I enjoyed the food, but it wasn't the experience I was hoping for. If they had branded themselves as a modern Mexican joint, I think I would have been pleasantly surprised, but by labeling themselves as Tex-Mex, they set themselves up for failure in my eyes (and mouth).   I heard the brunch is great, but I'm not too motivated to try it out.
Great food and nice ambience! Friendly staff and quick service! Their Corn pancakes are the best, and very filling!!

Simple enough: food is good, service mediocre to bad.   Details: El Dorado Benedict is delicious, and the waffles too, especially with fruit. Service is uniformly slow. Wait staff might see you once at most in the 40-60 minutes between placing your order and receiving your food. Look forward to another ten minutes just waiting for someone to run your card. Nary an apology or word of concern for the wait. Wait staff aren't overtly rude; they just don't seem to give a rat's ass about you or notice that you're there. This is not a one-time opinion -- I've been there 4 times for brunch (the food is worth the trip); each time the service has been the same, across multiple servers and times. A shame, since their menu is wonderful. Their management would do well to add some cooks, change their waiters, or both.   In summary, go for a leisurely and tasty brunch, but make sure you enjoy your company, because you'll be chatting with them for a long long time.

This is the second time I have been here, this time just for drinks. They have a fabulous selection of tequila and served in different volumes so you can try truly excellent tequila at an affordable price. Our server was super helpful and nice to chat with. I keep meaning to get here for brunch (last dinner was excellent) - one day we'll make it!

Pretty good, with many different menu options.  Their chips are served warm, and so light and crispy it's hard to stop eating them. I've tried the enchiladas, as well as the quinoa stuffed poblano. Both items were good, but I wish they were spicier (then again, I like my food pretty spicy). If you save room for dessert try the chocolate ancho pecan pie - delicious!

If you like jalapenos wrapped in bacon and top-notch margaritas, this is the place for you. The atmosphere is cozy but not cramped and the menu gives you plenty of options. It is a bit overpriced in my opinion, but the quality dishes and friendly service make up for it.

I had the chicken enchiladas around 13$. Were a bit dry w/ the verde sauce but I did prefer that over the mole. Used the yelp deal of free chips/salsa.  I had a finer honey margarita that was STRONG! I wasn't able to finish it:(

The menu at the Eldorado offers a wide-range of dishes to choose from which left us excited from the start. Our table went with the fish tacos, the pork adobo, chicken enchiladas, and the spinach and cheese enchiladas. Of these dishes the best, in terms of flavor, was the pork adobo. This dish offered chunks of pork, onions, and other vegetables in a hearty mole sauce. The fish tacos were just kind of bland. Two at our table ordered this entree and both said, "They were just okay. We've had better." Both diners who ordered the enchiladas simply said their dishes were okay. There seemed to be an overall lack of flavor across the board in the entree dishes, as well as the salsa served with the chips and salsa basket to start. (Free with our Yelp check-in.) Our service was good. We made a reservation and were seated on time. Drinks were good and refilled quickly. Noise level was high due to the tall, open industrial-look ceilings.
Great dinner here during restaurant week. Margaritas are awesome!! The pulled pork and enchiladas were amazing. Highly recommend!
Best margarita and chicken and mushroom burrito I have ever had. The appetizers where great too. Will be back!

This is the place you want. Go here. You won't regret it.   This instantly landed a firm spot in my all-time favorite restaurants.  A group of us came here on a whim for Sunday brunch, and luckily only had to wait 30-40 minutes. My cohorts ordered the most glorious looking, fully loaded Bloody Marys. I was nursing a hangover that even hair of the dog couldn't cure, so I stuck with OJ, but I would definitely make the 3 hour drive again just to order one. Stuffed olives, peppers, pickles, oh my.   The entire menu looked appetizing. No really, the entire thing. And I'm a picky eater. I eventually went with the Gringo Burrito.. wait for it... AND the french toast. Two full-sized entrees. The burrito was huge: stuffed with all kinds of veggie/ meaty/ potato-y magic and other stuff I don't remember because I was in food ecstasy. Then topped with a green sauce that blew my mind. The french toast was thick and sweet, made with vanilla and cinnamon crispy goodness, I didn't even use maple syrup it was so flavorful.  I had about a quarter of the burrito and two slices of the french toast left that I boxed up for my long drive home, and you can bet it was gone inside my 50 mile mark.   This astronomical food brought me back to life after a weekend of sin juice & mayhem, this is true, but I will absolutely be making more visits here in the future. So incredibly good.

Not disappointing. Start with some tequila - your knowledgable server will steer you in the direction of a taste sensation. Their special margaritas are pretty darn swell too (e.g. there was a spicy specialty that darn if I can't remember the name now). The pork dishes are just great (smoked pulled pork, Machaca burrito). I ventured out for the catfish this visit and really liked it - not overly blackened, just spiced and tasty with pickled red onions. The spinach and mushroom enchiladas were had by the wife - simply delicious mushrooms with verde salsa.  Good service. Only suggestion - give a guy some chips on the house. No kids menu but they will make smaller quesadillas, etc.
Over priced, food was less than fair tasting. Only positive, pretty plate. I wouldn't come back or order Mexican food from here but I may try the BBQ if I had to come back.
One of my top spots in Madison for a spicy margarita. Top pick is the blazing saddle, smoking gun in a close second. Also, the Texas torpedoes are killer.

Have had brunch here twice with my girlfriend.  It was busier on Sunday than it was Saturday, but we sat at the bar both times and got seated almost right away.  The service was really good, friendly bartenders, and the food came out quickly.  She really likes the Bloody Marias.  The blue corn pancakes are really good and we enjoyed everything we have gotten so far.  Great place for brunch, we'll definitely be back.

Possibly the best happy hour I've ever experienced. Got 3 happy hour apps, my wife and I were totally full...epinadas and tacos were mind blowing. Margaritas were great, and dirt cheap. Our server Ryan was helpful and friendly.

Deciding to eat early we had our choice of seating and choose a window side booth.  Starting with an order of chips that included three styles of dipping sauces.  Our favorite, which seems to be the favorite of others, was the very tasty and very spicy pineapple jalapeño dip.  Our waitress offered more dip as we soaked it all up with the light chips.   My wife ordered the street tacos which were small, simple, but tasty.  I ordered the slow-braised Pork Adobo which had tasty pieces of pork with red rice in a delicious dark mushroom sauce topped with fresh avocado.  I should have ordered it extra spicy.   This great Mexican food dinner was complemented by outstanding tequila margarita that was served on ice, but was NOT water downed as you might normally expect.       We were very happy with the great service and high food quality.  I don't think anything on the menu would be a bad choice. Ask your server what the regulars normally order if you are not sure.  We come from southern California where the Mexican food is top notch and plentiful.  If I may add.......this establishment in Madison does it right.

Thank you for ruining my birthday. I've been looking forward to brunch all week to celebrate my birthday. We got there at 9:00 and were promptly seated. After waiting 1 hr for our food and watching a table for 8 that came after us get food, drinks and more food, our food came.....,ice cold. my husband was furious and , even though the manager apologized and offered free food, walked out. An apology just doesn't cut it when a person is that angry. What is happening to the food fight restaurants? This is the second time we've been to the food fight chain this summer and the second same exact experience.

Chicken enchiladas were nearly inedible--corn tortillas were thin and stiff with bone-dry macerated chicken. (Seafood enchilada was similarly terrible, and expensive). Beans were bland and rice overcooked.  Tenderloin was decent, and chef's tacos were ok, they managed to rise above bland.  A 30 minute wait turned into 1.5 hours-- ok due to busy night, but we could have done without the snark when the friend we were supposed to meet after dinner stopped by and had a drink at the empty seat at our table. (More snark after asking server's whereabouts even though we were sitting with dry drinks for 20 min)  Bartender was a single bright spot. He was efficient and friendly. Margaritas were pretty good, too.  Overall, the dinner took 3 painful hours.

Come here for Brunch! Order the Huevos Rancheros.  I've eaten here for dinner and must say I was not impressed, but the Saturday and Sunday brunch is phenomenal--I rate it best in Madison. The Huevos Rancheros are the best I have ever eaten. (I tend to try huevos rancheros wherever I go and few can compare). Also exceptional--the biscuits and gravy, and the bacon.   Note this brunch that I highly recommend is not a buffet style brunch, but everything on the menu is delicious.

Overpriced. Nice staff, in spite of having to listen to the owner-or-whoevers stupid self-produced "country" music all night. That didn't help the dining experience much at all; I was annoyed after 15 minutes, I can't imagine having to listen to that all the time. The walk home through the silent construction dinosaurs on Willy street at night was more interesting than the food.

Ok, I've tried this place several times over some years, and we went back two nights  ago. The drinks were good, and we've had decent appetizers in the bar before.  But for dinner - not so good.  I had seafood enchiladas - 18.95 for three thin tubes of crispy tortilla filled with some sort of seafood paste.  Served with a side of unseasoned black beans and rice.  No salad, no vegetable, and they charge extra for chips and salsa. My husbands chicken enchilada mole was slightly more generous, but still very mediocre.  Painted with mole, but dry.  The food there is very conceptual - it looks pretty but doesn't taste good. So, I would stick to the drinks and appetizers.  My theory as to why they are busy - one of the few places in the neighborhood with parking.

The service was really great, don't be afraid to ask the waiters for recommendations. Also with the free chips and salsa they are very generous with the amount of chips it'll be plenty for four people!  Baja fish tacos: a very recommended dish at this place and very tasty! I'd recommend getting the mahi mahi blackened instead of fried because it really enhances the flavors. The beans and rice are fairly average but always a good side. Pasilla chicken enchilada: can get it with verde or mole sauce. The verde was very flavorful and the chicken was great. Again, it was just fairly average but still good.   One plus is that they offer vegan options, vegetarian options, and gluten free options so they are very versatile.

Unique breakfast menu but I'm never blown away by my experience here. The last time I was there I ordered their eggs Benedict and my eggs were poached completely hard, I asked for runny eggs. When I asked the waitress to bring me new eggs she was very sassy about it. The next batch of eggs she brought out were also hard, after asking for yet another set of eggs I finally got runny eggs on my third try.   Its a shame because the menu always sounds so good to me!

Eldorado Grill first came on our radar when we tried their Texas torpedos at Taste of Madison. While there's not much new about a bacon wrapped jalapeno popper, their addition of shrimp and the just-right amount of cheese caught our attention. Our two visits to the restaurant since then have both been solid. My spice loving husband is a huge fan of the pork adobo, which although it is offered extra spicy, he finds the heat sufficient in the original preparation. The guacamole chalupas feed my love of all things avocado and cheese. As far as drinks, if you are a tequila fan, you can't go wrong with the 100% agave margarita. I like my margarita to actually taste of tequila and not just sweet and sour, and this margarita fits the bill. We liked it enough on our first visit to bring the in-laws back on their next visit to town- a high vote of approval!
This is a food fight restaurant and they always do a great job.  Staff is friendly.  Great margaritas and we also really like the mango habanero salsa...spicy but awesome.

Sunday Brunch: The Chicken Fried Chicken is ah-maze-ing! If you're hungry (possibly hung over) and looking for some comfort food, this is the menu item to try. The biscuit is perfectly done (i.e., not dry at all), the gravy is awesome, the chicken is moist with a perfectly light-and-crispy outside and the egg is an added bonus in the mix. It comes with hash browns which are also wonderful! I'll be back!
El Dorado brunch is AMAZING. Please eat their mango-pineapple french toast. It is amazing.   Margaritas at night are pretty awesome too!

It was ok. Not a wow experience.   Food portions were huge. I had the bbq pork sliders which were ok.  Also had the vegan chili which was very good.  Tacos were ok.  It wasn't bad food just mediocre and I probably wouldn't choose to back.    Service was ok.   Server was nice. But she seemed very busy.  I wouldn't say best service but not bad either.

After waiting 30 minutes past the reservation time for our group, and then being treated with outright hostility by the manager, we won't be returning to El Dorado   despite liking lots of other restaurants owned by this large group in Madison.   We went to El Dorado Grill on Sept. 12 with reservations for a party of eight & arrived  on time.  After waiting 15 minutes past the reservation time, we checked in with the  hostess.  We did the same at 25 minutes since they were now serving groups of  four that didn't have reservations, and suggested that they consider pulling to  tables of four together.   At 30 minutes, we asked to see the manager.  This guy (about 6'3" and going about 240) ground my hand hard as he introduced himself.  I said that we had been waiting now for 30 minutes past our reservation time.  He said he wouldn't kick out other patrons (group at a table of 8 that were lingering talking after paying the bill).  When I suggested he could pull two tables of four together, the manager said,  "I've been in this business for 20 years.   Are you telling me what to do?"  I told him that  we were just trying to have a nice evening with our guests and wished that he'd work with us.  He said,  "if you want to ruin your evening that's your problem!" and glared at me.  (By the way, I am a grey haired guy in his 60's and was accompanied by my wife was pretty shocked by this guy's behavior.)     Five minutes later they pulled two tables of four together and seated us.  The manager never even apologized for the delay.    This place used to be good when Tex Tubbs ran it.  It is running on its past reputation.

Went for brunch this morning with a group.  They take reservations and sat us on time.  The wait staff in general looked tired and possibly hungover, but if I was 10 years younger and without children, I probably would be too on a Sunday morning.  At any rate, they got the job done.  They offered a nice array of breakfast drinks. The Bloody Marys were adequately garnished.  I opted for the blueberry bacon pancakes.  Normally I am a bit of bacon purist and prefer my bacon on the side, but I was pleasantly surprised by the combination.  Many of the other brunch entrees looked quite appetizing, and if I go back, I would likely order one of the more Mexican dishes.

Over 50 types of Tequila? I had no idea! There are actually tequila's that are triple the price of a bottle of Dom Perignon Champagne. Their selection of wine was also quite good. Alcohol aside, the pork chops were perfect. 2-3 inches thick and succulent. I wasn't all that impressed with the cheese enchilada, but that is more my fault for deciding to try something that I normally don't eat. So, the pork chop gets a five star!
Eldorado has the best Margaritas in the city. It's most likely from the best selection of Tequila around. Creative menu with amazing appetizers.

Hands-down the best breakfast (well, brunch) in Mad-town.  Yippee Hash is a personal fave, but one really can't go wrong with any of the dishes (I've tried about 8 and been happy every time.)  Be sure to get a side of their house-made chipotle puree - it's divine.  Be prepared for a relaxed dining environment, as you will not be rushed.  On the flip-side, you'll also wait a bit longer for your food.  The old-time country background music just adds to the western ambience.  So, kick back, enjoy the experience and bring a paper (or order a bloody) if you are the ancy-type.

I wanted to give Eldorado Grill a great review but our experience was not great.  My parents were in town and the asked if we could go to a nice breakfast.  Had not been to Eldorado Grill but read some good reviews on the web and their Southwest breakfast menu was appealing.  Arrived Sunday at noon and there was a 45 minutes wait, fine, expected.  After being seated in the outside area a waiter arrived and attempted to take our drink order.  He was not sure if they could make the drink we wanted, asked the bartender, came back with confusing info, had to clarify again, our drinks arrived almost 20 minutes later, girl who delivered drink said they were a different drink then we ordered, brought them back to the bar, the waiter showed up 5 minutes later with the same drink and said they were the ones we ordered.  It took him 20 minutes to return to take our food order.  Our food took almost another hour!!! When it arrived my dads pancakes were to tough he could not cut them with a fork.  My moms poached huevos rancheros were cooked well and not very tasty. My pork burrito was good. The hostess did come over sometime after we were done and said they were taking the pancakes and 2 drinks of our bill.   Our waiter continued to offer slow services even as the restaurant was now empty, I had to run our charge card to the bar due to the waiter no returning to retrieve it after 15 minutes. We did not see him again.  Very disappointing.

The only place I know where I can get a seat for a weekend brunch without waiting. Normally, that would be a bad thing, but I think people just haven't discovered this place in the morning yet. Lots of windows and a Southern exposure make this place a bright way to start your morning.  They've got eggs and pancakes with a slight Southwestern twist. The brunch is much more reasonably priced than the dinners. And the staff are actually friendly first thing in the morning.

Top-notch place already, but wife and I did Sunday brunch that was as good as we have ever had. French toast with pineapple-mango topping and huevos rancheros with a verde sauce. INCREDIBLE.   Well worth the trip into town

El Dorado Grill is located inside an old candy factory next door to Ground Zero coffee shop.  They specialize in Tex-Mex food and have a huge menu.  The restaurant has a nice warm atmosphere with all kinds of tequila bottles lined on single shelves near the ceiling.  They also play old time country music which really compliments the atmosphere.    Chips and Salsa are quite good.  The Margaritas here are delicious!    The handmade Tamales are filled with shredded seasoned pork and are very moist and tasty.    The enchiladas with Oaxacan Mole Sauce is really good however, I'm not a fan of the sour cream they drizzle on top (I love sour cream and I know other places that drizzle SC on top of their mole sauce, but I really think it interferes with the sauce so I usually ask for no sour cream).   The Chicken Chalupa is good.  It's like a tostada with grilled seasoned chicken (wish it was a little more seasoned and spicy), mixed greens and pico de gallo and a dollop of SC).   Recently had the Machaca Pork Chalupa which is I think is more flavorful than the chicken.  Recently had the K.W.'s Texas Smoked Brisket - delicious!  The brisket is coated with 8 secret spices and slow roasted for 12 hrs.  Can't go wrong with that!  It's served on Texas toast which gets pretty soggy/mushy - it should just be served on the side or not at all since there are yummy little corn cakes served with this dish as well.  They really pile on the mashed potatoes (a bit much if you ask me) and the blackeyed peas are ok.  I really need to try more of their desserts.  I've only had the Chocolate Ancho Pecan Pie.  It was pretty good however the top of the pie was a little on the burnt side.

I went with a group of four. We had reservations and our booth was ready when we arrived.  We had Tamales and Seafood Cakes as an appetizer. The seafood cakes were amazing! I had the pork burrito as an entree and I loved it.   The others ordered chicken fajitas, fish tacos and tenderloin and all enjoyed it as well. A couple people tried my burrito and said they would try that next time too.   Our server was great too. I can't wait to go back!

El Dorado Grill is a great Tex-Mex restaurant in Madison... The atmosphere is wonderful and the overall dining experience is great but the service was rather slow but still friendly... The food was really good. The fish cakes was outstanding with a great punch of flavor, the BBQ Tex-Mex sliders had a great smokey flavor to it witch I really loved also the fajitas are really good with a great touch of spice. Overall I really liked El dorado grill and I hope to return soon!!!!
So disappointed...Service was below average...had to ask for plates and just the basics...meal was average...
Exceptional breakfast with great service. Attended to my allergy needs in high regards. Super impressed
Great margaritas, happy hour and service. I like the food, though it's expensive.

Recently discovered Eldorado Grill, after 25 years of buzzing all over Madison.  Been there three times in the past 6 weeks, all excellent experiences.  This place is a combination of Southern and Southwestern, with some Central Mexico influences. Rather eclectic execution of all three cuisines.    Read the menu carefully, and ask your server questions.  If you are lucky enough to be served by Walker, game on!  The guy taught me more about tequila in 10 minutes than I've learned in my 40 plus years of cocktailing.  Ignore the negative reviews, try the place and make up your own mind.     Excellent Saturday/Sunday brunch.
appetizers super delicious  Main course not so good Big selection of Alcohol but relatively expensive  Good service, overall experience just OK.

Sunday brunch, 5 people, 11AM.  Restaurant was busy, but there was no wait for a table.  Let's start with the food/drinks: Bloody Mary was too garlicky, I only drank half.  Everyone seemed pleased with their food; huevos rancheros were well salted/spiced.  If this review only considered the quality of food, it'd be 4 stars.  Onto the service...our waiter was an EMBARRASSMENT.  * Our waiter neglected to fill our water and coffee throughout our visit.  It got so bad that my boyfriend grabbed the coffee and water carafe from the bussers' area and refilled our drinks on more than one occasion.  Somehow none of the other waitstaff noticed us either.  * Tables that placed their orders after us received their food before us.  Our meal took an hour in getting to the table.  * Our waiter never asked how the meal tasted or if he could get us anything.  It took us asking repeated times to actually get more gravy/syrup.  * Our waiter only visited our table 3 times and spoke no more than 10 total words to us.  Working in food service requires communication with your customer; this guy must have missed class that day.  * When the check came, we all had our cash on the table and one person had their credit card out.  The waiter walked up to our table, grabbed the credit card, without saying anything, and ran it.  I was excited to add Eldorado Grill to our growing list of good brunch spots to enjoy with out of town guests, but after this experience I will recommend going elsewhere.
Coming from a Texan....this was the best "Mexican/ Tex-mex" brunch if found in madison

We love this place. Pretty sure we are recognized as regulars for the Happy Hour for margaritas and app specials. They open at 4:30 and quite often we are waiting at the door. Great margaritas and nice tequila selection for neat pours. Texas Torpedoes are great and if you haven't tried their brunch you are missing out stop in and make sure someone in your group orders the awesome Eldorado french toast and someone else gets the Machaca Pork Burrito you won't be disappointed.

We tried Eldorado for the first time this weekend- it was fairly busy on a Friday night, but not so much that it felt crowded.  Wait staff were super- the mojitos were good, and the salsa was yummy.  I had the pork tenderloin, potatoes, gravy, and beans.  The tenderloin was a little pink for me (sorry, but I grew up afraid of trichinosis), although it was tasty.  The gravy was interesting and the potatoes were good.  The beans, not so much, but whatever.  We did have the chocolate bread pudding, and while I'm a huge fan of traditional bread pudding (Famous Dave's rocks, by the way), this was quite good.    I'm not sure I'd hurry back, but it was a good experience.
This place is great!  Their margaritas are strong and from scratch.  I would totally recomend the Lobster, Shrimp and Seafood Enchilada - YUMM-O!!
Awesome atmosphere!   Very accomodating to large groups!   Food was also delicious but it was the bloody mary's that was the bomb! Not only did it tasted f-ing delicious, I had to have the recipe!

I love, love, love this place! I have been to Madison at least once a year for business and I found this place last time I was in town. I am in town again now and went back for seconds. Fabulous margaritas! Excellent service. They are super generous with booze which is a plus. Coming from Chicago, people are often stingy with the alcohol but expensive with the price. You can enjoy Happy Hour here until 6:30p. Everything I've had to eat and drink has been wonderful. The blackend fish tacos are so tasty! Warning about the spicy margarita, if you order it on a Monday, you may be getting last weeks chili infused tequila which equals pretty spicy. I like spicy but that drink was a bit much for me. I'm not holding it against them though. You always take a risk when you try something new. Trust me, this is a must visit for dinner if your are in town or a regular. I will miss it when I go back home and hope to return soon.

Mexican food AND barbecue!? AWESOME! It's the most expensive Mexican restaurant I've ever been to, but they serve more upscale versions of the traditional dishes. I've been happy with everything I've ordered here, and the margaritas are great.

Revised 1/4/15: We went for brunch and the place was buzzing! Tip: call ahead if you're on the way and they will put your name down for a table. Wait time was under 30 minutes, not bad for such a busy spot! The blue corn pancakes were really tasty and the syrup was a perfect combo with a unique spicy flavor! I loved the light fixture made of a fire pit ring, so neat!   Oriignal Post: It may have been just where we were seated, but we were on a porch that was freezing and it did not make the dining experience enjoyable.
THE BEST Margaritas in Madison! Texas torpedoes are my fav!
One of my favorite places in Madison (and that is saying something with fine array of restaurants around!)

Since moving away from Madison, Eldorado is one of those restaurants I miss. The atmosphere is nice...tex mex meets modern design. Very hip.   In regards to the food, dinner entrees don't really stick out. What I do continue to crave, however, is the brunch menu. I LOVE the blue corn pancakes. Highly recommended. I also recommend you wash them down with a mimosa.  My early-morning-empty-tummy misses you, Eldorado.

You must get the blazing saddle and grilled spinach enchiladas! El Dorado has a great spin on Tex Mex with great food and tequila drinks. The service is always timely, and we have always enjoyed our meal. I highly recommend you give them a taste! It won't disappoint!

I really, really like Eldorado. I love the physical space and the warm, cozy ambiance. I have been here several times, most often for brunch. The brunch menu has a Southwest feel but you can still get all your classic favorites. The smoked salmon Benedict is my favorite. On one occasion my poached eggs came out with hard yolks. I'm someone who doesn't like to complain but I was disappointed enough to mention it to our server. He was back with 2 freshly poached eggs for me minutes later. On my most recent visit I had the Eldorado eggs. I love that they are served on blue corn cakes but I still thought the dish lacked some kind of wow factor. The dinner menu is also diverse and does have some tasty selections. But for me the thing Eldorado does best is their classic margarita. They use fresh lime and no neon green syrup. It's not too sweet and is one of the freshest tasting margaritas you can find in Madison. Which also leads to the next point, which is that this is a great happy hour spot. Cozy up at the bar with a marg, chips and salsa and you'll be a happy camper!   Service is hit or miss, which is the main reason I'm giving 4 stars. The last time I was here we hardly saw our server and she seemed very disinterested and disconnected. She never refilled our coffee (we had to ask for more when she dropped off our check very prematurely) and we sat with our empty plates in front of us for a full 15 minutes. The host walked by and saw our plates and scooped them up, which was very kind of him!   Assuming your server is having a good day and you start with a margarita, you'll be happy with Eldorado!

Two different reviews for breakfast then dinner.  Brunch: 4/5 For the life of me, I canNOT get past the first listing on the menu. I think they are just good enough to not look elsewhere. The Eldorado eggs - two poached eggs on top of a blue corn cake with tomatoes, grilled scallions, and smoked bacon, with scallion-lime cream sauce (on the side for me). Served with greens and house potatoes. All of it combined just works. The most interesting thing is the blue corn pancake. They are small, with a slight hint of sweetness. Texture is still pancake-y, not gritty like cornmeal. I like 'em. Also, they know how to poach. The hit-or-miss is the consistency of how warm/hot/cool the dish comes to the table. 4/5  Bloody Mary - very good. Tied for second favorite in town. It's house made, decent garnishes, good flavor. 5/5  My brunch buddies LOVE the Hit The Trail Flapjacks - they are the yummy, healthy pancake. BIG pancake with nuts and berries all over it. It really does look great (I had a bite, tastes good too!) I love that they have a pancake that's not whip cream crap all over it. But I need my savory eggs in the morning, and these flapjacks are just too much food to add as a "side." 4/5  Dinner: 3/5 They call themselves a "smokehouse" and I'm checking out local "BBQ" places. So I thought I'd try the BBQ.  Chicken "Enchiladas" - this one really bugged me. It's a FLAUTA (or Taquito, depending on where you're from). Not an enchilada! Google it. Not many places in Madison do this, so I understand why people are raving about them, but shesh, these are just average for any Southerner, and I mean as a flauta/taquito. 2/5  Baja Fish Taco - Mahi mahi fish, blackened. It was average-good. Sub limes for cheese and aioli. Slaw coulda had a little more pizzaz, but overall, this was the best dish of the night. 3/5  Pork ribs - not real BBQ, maybe oven "BBQ?" The meat was not dry, but mildly moist; not tender, but not brittle, fatty short rib, and no "smoke." The sauce was ok (tangy). 2/5  Side note: I saw the chicken friend chicken - this is not traditional (pounded with softer breading) CFC for a Southerner. This version is a chicken breast deep fried, but it was a very BIG portion. It beat up the woman who ordered it.   Overall, I really like the brunch and bloody. The dinner was ok, but I'd probably go again with friends.  (On BBQ list, place is 9th.)

Eldorado has the best margaritas I've had in Madison. Tex Tubb's is a close second, but Eldorado is the best. Check out their happy hour, the drinks are cheaper! You can even get discounts on neat pours of their amazing tequila selection.  I've been here quite a few times and never been disappointed. The drinks are great, the staff is wonderful, and the food is fantastic.  The brunch deserves its own paragraph. It's my favorite brunch in town. Good drinks and wonderful tex-mex food. I'm reading a 3-star review on the sidebar as I write this and I can't believe it. Someone complaining about no free chips and salsa (they're really cheap), the queso (which we've ordered twice and the waitstaff always explained was not normal queso) and the lack of frozen margaritas... seriously? If you want cheap, by-the-numbers big-box type mexican, go to Pedro's. This restaurant is for people that enjoy good food and drinks.  Sorry, back to the brunch. I've had half a dozen items off the brunch menu and loved every one. If you come here on Sunday morning, you might want to make a reservation because everyone knows what a great brunch they have and they all come on Sunday.   It's a bit more expensive than your average Mexican or Tex-Mex place, but the quality of the food, drinks, and service is well worth it.
Amazing brunch!!  The blueberry bacon pancakes and the hit the trail pancakes are the best pancakes in the state- and you can't find a better margarita anywhere.

We came here for brunch on Sunday morning. We made a reservation for 10:00 AM. Upon entering, the restaurant was about 3/4 full. By the time we left an hour later, the restaurant was packed.  We started our meal with the Texas Torpedoes. They were highly recommended, and I am glad we order them. They may have been the highlight of our brunch. The bacon was cooked perfectly, and the shrimp inside the pepper surrounded by cheese provided an added a punch of flavor.   I ordered the El Dorado Eggs. I am a huge fan of biscuits, so I subbed a biscuit for the corn cakes. The waitress had no problem with the substitution. I also ordered the cream on the side. I loved about the breakfast came with a side of greens. They were nicely dressed and added a lightened flare to the meal.   The only reservation my entire table had with our meals were the house potatoes. We couldn't really figure out if they were good or not. They are not really fried crispy and are a little mushy. A different potato for sure. I'd rather have some nice red potatoes or more of a fried hash brown.   This place definitely deserves its four stars though. A true Madison gem!

The only thing I've ever had here is the spinach enchiladas at brunch.  They are so good, I'm afraid to try anything else, in fear that it won't measure up.  The cheese and spinach inside is soooo good and creamy, and the tortillas are just crispy enough.  The salsa on top is the freshest I've ever tasted.  The potatoes are good (when aren't potatoes at least good?), but I'm not a huge fan of beans (anywhere).  I'd like to sub the beans out for an egg, but the $2 substitution charge is something I refuse to pay.  Have fun trying the various Bloody Marys!

This was my first time at Eldorado Grill, and I really enjoyed the Southwestern ambiance: large leather booths, cacti, horseshoe decorations. Our server was prompt and friendly, and our steak fajitas were excellent! The sautéed vegetable medley really added to the steak flavor. However, we were slightly disappointed to see that chips and salsa were not complementary.

The brunch here is extensive and delicious. Although their standard brunch menu has plenty to make your decision difficult, I decided to go with their special - a chorizo, cheese, and onion omelet with salsa verde on top and crispy potato quarters on the side. This might have been one of the best omelets I've ever had, and I've had quite a few. A great unique change of pace compared to all the standard omelets out there.  They also make some mean bloody marys. I had the Bloody Maria, which comes with tequila instead of vodka. Although I wouldn't get it every time, it was very interesting and ultimately delicious with my meal. It also comes with a beer chaser shot.  Cool building, nice hardwood interior, and friendly service. I see a return trip in my future the next time I'm in Madison.

Definitely take advantage of the free chips and salsa for checking in!  We were able to sit outdoors in the heated tent area.  The restaurants indoor decor was nice, but there's something really nice about being able to eat outdoors in WI November! I had the honey-ginger margarita and would definitely have it again.  There's a nice tequila kick to the margarita that the ginger adds to.   For an entree, I had the fish tacos with fried mahi mahi.  It was good, but between the corn tortillas and fried fish, it felt a bit dry.  The slaw and aoli added some juice and flavor, but I could have used more.  I think if I had went with blackened fish instead, it'd have been better. I've heard brunch is phenomenal here so we'll likely be back!

I go here a lot and it is consistently delicious. More interesting than plain old Mexican or tex-mex. Nice big chips and salsa to start, and yummy house margaritas (both marked down for all night happy hour Mondays), and then it's hard to go wrong with the entrees.

Alright, I had to update my review after trying out Eldorado again. This time around, the experience was miles better. My sister and I went around 6 p.m. on a Tuesday, without a reservation, and were seated right away despite the seemingly busy restaurant. We used the free chips and salsa Yelp deal (well worth it) and enjoyed those and split a margarita before our main courses. The margarita was strong, but delicious!   I ordered the Smoked Pulled Pork (can't really ever go wrong with pulled pork) and it was so good. It was cooked perfectly and the chipotle potato salad that comes as one of the sides was AMAZING -- I might need to figure out how to make it at home.   My sister ordered the Fajitas, which is served with generous portions of chicken/peppers/guac/rice/beans and tortillas. They're set up where you have the ingredients in front of you on separate plates and then make the fajitas yourself, which is nice if you want to control your portions (and makes boxing up leftovers easier). She said they were tasty - no complaints there.   Service overall was friendly and attentive. The waiter seemed to consistently be on the lookout to fill our water glasses, which is always nice. Thanks, Eldorado, for giving us a great second experience!

Had reservations for Father's Day and they were busy. We were seated in the bar area, which is not nearly as inviting as the main room, so that was a disappointment. My Killer Bloody Maria was spicy hot and well garnished, but overall rather taste-free. I can do better at home. Brunch plates were good, but honestly not great. Temperatures a little off as if some components had been sitting around. We've been coming here since they opened, maybe 20 years ago, and I really want to love it, but I don't so much. Just okay.

Descriptive phrase: trendy Tex-Mex restaurant.  El Dorado Grill was a busy place for Sunday brunch, but we found a spot on their outside, porch-thing-room. It's a nice space, and service was attentive. Checking in on Yelp got us a free chips and salsa (I personally am wary of Mexican places that don't offer these for free to begin with).   I ordered the Breakfast Burrito ($9.19), which was full of scrambled eggs, chorizo, pico de gallo, black beans, and jack cheese. To be honest, there was an overpowering amount of beans and a lack of chorizo. The side of house potatoes were greasy-good, but the refried pinto beans were inedible. I couldn't place their taste, but it was not appealing. I will say the half of a burrito I had leftover for lunch the next day reheated quite well. Would I return? Probably not. It was okay.
Yah I really like this place! I would go early cause it can be hard to get in the restaurant. With a great selection of Margaritas and Bloody Marys and the Texas two- step . Parking nearby.

The vegetable goat cheese empanadas are easily the best thing I have eaten since I moved to Madison. The restaurant itself is very loud in peak times. People need to use their inside voices, but thats not the restaurants fault

We went here as a large group and had reservations. The wait was exceptionally long and at least half an hour longer than what we were told when we had arrived. Food was okay but everyone got served at different times and due to what could only have been lack of communication between staff, certain people at the bar were not cut off when they clearly should have been. I would not bring my family here if I knew the extent to which the patrons are permitted to inebriate themselves. Perhaps earlier in the day it is nicer. The salad I got was great but the portion was quite large and I felt bad wasting much of the chevre that came with it but there was just so much and it was not the type of dish to pack up well. Others in my party were not fans of the corn flapjacks with their meals although the rest of their food was good. The decor was nice. We parked down by the water and enjoyed the walk to the restaurant. Many beautiful homes and cute shops. The walk back from the restaurant was not as nice (re: drunk people) but thankfully the streets were well lit enough to avoid issues.
Solid food and service.  Couldn't find any fault  with our experience.  The highlight of the meal for me was the pickled onions they put on all plates.

Love the building and how they have it set up and the people that work there are very nice. But the food is very average at best and lacks the taste that wants to bring you back. Been there several times and wanting to love it, but just can't.

Delicious as always! I recommend their breakfast, lunch or dinner to anyone!! Today, came here for brunch and strayed away from my favorite mango mimosa and got raspberry instead...amazing! Yippie Vegetable Hash was fantastic and not too heavy. Prices for most brunch dishes are under $10! Super affordable for Madison breakfast. Wait was about 45 minutes, so we enjoyed the bar. Great meal.

I love the atmosphere of this place and the service is always great. I have heard such great things about their brunch but I have not yet gone for brunch yet. I can speak for the dinner though. Their margaritas were really goood and cheaap (it was some sort of special). They have a huge menu. The enchiladas and meats were good.

Last night we had a fabulous dinner at Eldorado Grill!  We went out with another couple who knew the menu really well.  We started with Texas Torpedo's...I'm not a spicy fan so I didn't have one but the other three at the table loved them!  I'm trying to make healthier choices so I went with the Thai Vegetable Fajitas.  They were fantastic!  Definitely plenty of food - great atmosphere and service.  I had three drinks while we were there (I'm making healthier food choice, not stopping drinking).  The first was the Iguana Margarita.  The melon flavored at a fun unique twist I'd never tasted in a margarita - definitely good, definitely strong.  Next I tried the Sangria.  It went really well with my dinner.  In the meantime my husband had ordered the 'Danger's Door County Cocktail' and I took a sip to try it.  Normally I would have stopped at two drinks...I immediately realized I had to had a Door County Cocktail of my own.  I'm not even sure how to describe it.  A tart, fruity drink that you know had a lot of booze but couldn't really taste that it was there...wonderful.    The food was great, the company fantastic, service wonderful, and I would go back for all those things but I honestly will definitely have to go back just to have another Danger's Door County Cocktail.

I'm so grateful that Ashley recommended us to visit Eldorado Grill for restaurant week! We managed to get seats within 20 minutes of calling. They set us down promptly and we quickly got settled with drinks and snacks to start!   I love our starter - this gigantic bowl of guacamole and chips. The chips came out hot, so either they made their chips (hurray!) or they heated it up at least. The guacamole tasted delicious and we could stop getting more. Took 2 baskets of chips to finish the guacamole among 4 people (Thanks Ashley!).  There was a myriad of drinks and if you're a fan of Tequila, you're in for a treat here! Onotse got Mojitos (2 actually, since it was that good), Ashley got a honey ginger alcoholic mix and Matt got a smokey tequila cocktail. Everyone enjoyed their drinks!   So, restaurant week - for serving so many people of the same dish, I'm impressed. The Green Chile Pork stew was PERFECTLY done. soft pork that tears apart with the fork, the green chile was aptly spiced, not too hot but keeps you warm. LOVE IT. Onotse got a GIGANTIC salad for only $1.29. and it comes with lots of spinach, walnuts and some other things. Ashley got the jalapeno poppers, which looked just like bacon wrapped dates but instead of dates, there's jalapeno. She said she would get it again, but you should share it with some other person.  Main dish, most of us got the smoked brisket. It was alright for me, not over the top, but the dish was a hearty meal. Lots of beans, lots of salad (no dressing), nice potato salad, lovely corn pancake (in place of corn bread). And the brisket was served on a piece of bread. Lots of meat to keep you full. But I was expecting more like braised beef, instead of spam-like texture? Definitely not something I would pick up again..  Finally, for dessert, I got the pecan chile pie. I didn't like the crust since I'm a cookie/graham cracker crust fan.. Also, there was no obvious chile spice in the pie.. tasted more like pecan chocolate pie. It was alright. Matt got the mole root beer (mole ice cream), but sadly it had peanuts so the rest of us got to try it. It was REALLY spicy. Don't think anyone can finish that lump of spicy ice cream. spicy and cold at the same time, what an experience!!  There's covered outdoor seating in the summer as well!

I've been to Eldorado several times in my occasional travels to Madison. I've always enjoyed the food, drink, and service.  I have to say tonight's meal was the best I've ever had there--green chili meatloaf with garlic mashed potatoes and collard greens.  I don't like barbecue sauce, so I asked to have that on the side, and pretty much ignored it, but the meatloaf lacked for nothing in taste or moisture.  The mashed potatoes were garlicky and delicious, and the collard greens were not the wilted green mess I'm accustomed to (from my dear Southern mama), but lightly cooked, with a smoky flavor to them.  Every meal I've had at Eldorado has been delicious, but this one takes the cake.  (No, I had no room for cake or any other dessert, and in fact took away half of my meal as leftovers--which I very much look forward to consuming!)
The food is ok, typically not what I would go out of my way for if I were seeking Tex-Mex. But their Blazing Saddle Margarita is fantastic!

BRUNCH is the way to begin an ongoing relationship with El Do.  Breakfast entrees are priced low for such big plates of food.  Indulge in a bloody or a rita to start your day off right.  Dinner is heavy duty and full of flavor.  Nightly specials and a righteous menu keep this place swinging.  The waitstaff is chill and gets the job done swiftly.  Finish your meal off with the superb creme brulee.  And again, best place for margarita, large selection of tequila and an overall fine bar selection.

My wife and I went to Eldorado Grill for New Years Eve 17'. The staff, while busy, was still attentive and expedient. Overall, the food was as to be expected from a TexMex restaurant in the Northern Midwest - but the margaritas made up for the food. Eldorado is certainly a welcome respite from the typical cheese and beer restaurants you would find in Madison.   I'd offer a strong recommendation for Eldorado for anyone looking for a good meal with decent drinks.

El Dorado is my absolute favorite place for brunch in Madison. For one: they take reservations. Hard to come by in this city! I get the chilaquiles every time (used to alternate with their quiche, but they removed it from the menu.) Their bloody marys are far and away better than anywhere else in the city. I also recommend getting a single slice of french toast on the side. You won't regret it.
Another mediocre Food Fight, Inc. disappointment. Service is friendly, atmosphere is nice, but the food is unsatisfying.

Excellent Monday happy hour all evening - the apps are half off so you can make a dinner out of them. The chips & salsa are addicting, but try not to fill up on just those! The margaritas are excellent as well; I've tried all the fruit ones (and they're great) but my favorites are the honey ginger one (and I don't even like ginger usually) and the blazing saddle. Brunch is pretty good too, but given the happy hour deal, I usually try to just go on Monday. In the summer they have a nice covered porch area too.

I've only been for dinner, just so ya know. But I've been for dinner like a hundred times. One of my favorite restaurants in Madison!   Delicious food. Fantastic margaritas (try the world famous version) and chips and salsa. Great atmosphere, very cool space.  Try the pork burrito, pork chalupa, southwestern fishcakes, pasilla chicken enchiladas with mole and the blackened catfish.  Yum.

I was so confused why this place got less than 5 stars until I tried their dinner once. But forget about that - I'm going to write about all the reasons I'm in love with their ridiculously FANTASTIC brunch!  1. They take reservations, which is rare for brunch spots in Madison. This makes it a great place to go with friends, family, visitors, etc. (or when you're anticipating a rough Saturday morning in your future).  2. It has great decorations. Yes, the bathrooms leave something to be desired (they're shared with the coffee shop next store), but the restaurant itself has a southwestern vibe that makes you feel comfortable.  3. The waitresses are very friendly and willing to help make suggestions for your order.  4. You can order chips & salsa...for breakfast.  5. The aforementioned chips & salsa are unlimited and they are simply amazing.  6. They have a great selection of mimosas and bloody marys, and are not sparing with the alcohol. Since I'm not a bloody mary person, I highly recommend the blackberry mimosa. Also, if you're feelin wild, try their margarita (formerly known as the Brunch margarita).  7. Their pineapple mango french toast is out of this world. I got it the first time I came (from my waitress's recommendation) and I haven't gotten anything else since.   8. Speaking on my boyfriends behalf, the chicken friend chicken biscuit is his go-to and he gets it every single time. This dish is mammoth and has all the mouthwatering flavors that make for a perfect brunch dish. It comes with potatoes, which I try to snag since they're super delicious.  Needless to say, you need to give this place a try for brunch. Or better yet, don't, and there will be more room for me!

I have only been to Eldorado Grill once and I have to say it was good.    We started with the street tacos and empanadas.  The flavors were quite full, but balanced.  The cheese in the empanadas was very rich, but the exterior was a lot lighter to balance it out.  The tacos were a bit laking in flavor, but ok for a lite bland flower.  I had the enchiladas.  My wife had the salmon.  I would highly recommend the salmon.  It was ample, perfectly done.  The glaze had the perfect amount of sweetness and seasoning.  The enchiladas were more like to small taquitos without any sauce.  The rice and beans that came with the enchiladas were ok, but a bit bland as well.    The pecan pie was pretty awesome.  It has chocolate chips on the bottom and on the crust.  I would prefer more praline instead of chocolate chips, but it was still pretty good.     I didn't have anything off the regular menu we only had the Restaurant Week Menu.  There regular menu may be quite different.

Horrible service. We arrived and were told there was a 30 minute wait, or we could sit and eat at the bar. We were happy to sit at the bar, which was not crowded. The bartender did acknowledge us, but never asked us if we wanted a drink or a food menu. He waited on a few people, never again looking our way. About 10 minutes go by and he walked over to a few girls at the bar and started flirting with them. We got up and left. Bartender never noticed. Would not go back.
Slow service, confused host; but great vibe for brunch w/ mimosas!

Hadn't been here for several years and was really looking fwd to it .Made reservations and went for dinner, boy was I disappointed, they changed their menu and its definatley NOT mexican! Thai Burrito? and other NON MEXICAN entrees , I won't be back very limited menu choices  We'll have to find another place when we want  REAL mexican.

Just a quick update...  Came here right after work and was extremely hungry. Got a table right away, it was pretty busy  though. Ended up checking in on Yelp and got a free order of chips and salsa, and ended up getting a 2nd refill on both, which was nice since our wait for our food was a good forty five minutes. I ended up getting the Southwestern Fishcakes off the appetizer section on the menu, which was hard for me to choose it was a toss up between three different items. I was happy with what I got though!  Our waitress was fantastic as well! :)

I've been to this place one time and we were not impressed. I had been having a conversion with a manager on a work project about the lack of quality mexican in Madison and he pointed me to this place. Unfortunately, this manager was not very good, so I probably should have stuck with my gut and crossed this off the list of places to try.   How did I feel when I left the restaurant? The portions were fairly small for the price and the food was not that great. Smaller portions are actually something I tend to prefer these days, so you don't have to have a lot of food, but this is also texmex. Mexican portions should be large since it's fairly cheap to make and is definitely a type of food you can box up and enjoy as a leftover.   So, the hunt for great mexican in Madison continues. I've heard of a couple solid places of late. Stay tuned for upcoming reviews.

I have mixed feelings about Eldorado Grill. The flavors: sensational. The atmosphere: inviting. The portions: meh. The price: upscale. The service: mixed.  The two of us originally tried to visit Eldorado Grill on Saturday night. The hostess seemed very confused. Several patrons were standing near the hostess area complaining about the slow service. The hostess finally told us it would be a two hour wait and we decided to try another time. No big deal and the fact that they were busy is a good sign, but the hostess definitely didn't seem to have it together.  Since we were in the area, we tried again on Sunday and were able to be seated immediately. The hostess told us we could either sit in the bar area for the Happy Hour menu or the dining room for the regular menu. We elected for the dining area. The room is beautiful with exposed wood beams, a high shelf w/liquor bottles, a beaten copper mantle on the fireplace, a mural above the fireplace and glassed in cabinets filled with Western pulp books and various southwestern paraphernalia.  Our waitress was friendly enough and brought over the menus. The tequila and mescal menu is impressive -- many varieties I had never heard of and they have various flight options available.  Where I'm from, inexpensive southwestern restaurants are ubiquitous. So as I was perusing the dinner menu I was somewhat apprehensive. The prices were about $5 higher than I would expect, and they charge for the chips and salsa. Nevertheless, we ordered the chips and salsa. I also ordered the Pasilla Chile Chicken Enchilada and my partner had the Grilled Lobster, Shrimp, and Crab Enchiladas. Our waitress brought a huge basket of chips as well as a small dish of salsa. The salsa was incredible - fresh, bright, and the charred pepper flavor was intense. We really enjoyed it. I was mildly concerned as we still had a large basket of chips, but no salsa left. Our waitress came back by and asked if we'd like more salsa and then refilled it from a pitcher. I can't really describe just how good the salsa was!  When my chicken enchiladas came, I was again mildly concerned. Three small tightly rolled enchiladas with just a hint of salsa verde, a scoop of rice and a small side of beans. It's a reasonable portion of food, but certainly not what we're used to in the midwest and for a hefty price. Once I started eating though, I was very pleased. The chicken enchiladas and salsa verde were so flavorful. The rice was dense with almost a corn bread consistency. I tried some of my partner's seafood enchiladas and again the flavors were spot on.  By the end of the meal, I was very impressed with the quality of the food. The portions could have been a little bigger, the prices a little lower, but the quality was so good, it was worth it. I'm probably not going to head back there if I'm feeling famished, but if I'm in the mood for some quality southwestern food, this is a great option.

Oh man, oh man! Eldorado is absolutely amazing!! Easily one of the best brunches I've had in Madison.  First, let me preface my review by saying that I normally avoid Bloody Marys like the plague. Despite my propensity for alcoholic drinks, it's probably my last possible choice. In fact, I'd probably choose water (ewww) over it.  Anyways, given the massive hype its Bloody Marys have gotten, and by hype, I mean my friends constantly talking about how it's the best thing ever (eye roll)... I decided to give them a chance.  My Bloody Mary arrived with a sampler of beer (starting things off right already), and was pretty delicious. Of course, it's not the best thing ever like my friends claim, but it was pretty damn good.   The fact that I highly enjoyed it should say a lot already. It was perfectly spiced, and had enough alcohol to counterbalance the normally overwhelming mix.   For food, I got their Texas Two Step, which definitely lived up to its name. There's nothing more Texan than two ginormous buttermilk biscuits topped with a fried egg, cheese, bacon, sausage and gravy. I have never had something so delicious, yet so, so terrible for me.  I definitely plan on coming here more often, so who knows, I might even start ordering Bloody Marys elsewhere (yeah right).

El Dorado is my favorite spot for tex-mex goodies and a good bloody.   Have been here many times and finally get a chance to write a review after coming here for restaurant week.  They have an amazing drinks list, from the classical cocktails to high-end tequila, bloody maries, margaritas and even MEZCAL! The bloody Mary remains my go-to and favorite in town!  They have a wide selection of dishes, from vegetarian options, to catfish, and barbeque foods and other unique tex-mex dishes. You will always have a new experience when you come here. Not just amazing main dishes, but also well done, filling appetizers!  They do a whole day Monday happy hour with a number of cheaper priced small plates and drinks on special!  They are very busy during brunch time and also on the weekend, but luckily they do take reservations! So I recommend you call ahead before you stop by!

Stopped here to meet up with friends for brunch on a Saturday morning.  This place was packed! We were lucky we got a spot as soon as we did without a reservation.  It's a smaller restaurant with a cozy feel to it.  There's a full bar at one end of the restaurant.    They're known for their southwestern food and there was a lot of those options for breakfast.  I got the Chorizo and Egg Street Tacos. A tortilla with chorizo, scrambled eggs, and some of your favorite taco toppings along with refried beans and potatoes...it was a tremendous meal!  Of course when I got them my eyes said, "Two tacos? You'll eat this in no time."  At the end of the second taco my stomach said, "Please no more, I'm too full!."
$12 for a freaking corn, bean and cheese quesadilla?!  You've got to be kidding me.    How much could that have cost to make?  $1.50?

Went for brunch today, I love the late morning drink selections as well as the fact that you can get chips, salsa, guacamole at 10am without being judged. The smoked chicken enchiladas are my all time favorite (not breakfasty but cheesy, good salsa verde ,and portion is just right). The margaritas hit the spot and be sure to ask for the house made hot sauce- adds just the right amount of heat to any meal.

During my first brunch visit I ordered the eggs benedict and wasn't a huge fan. I've heard a lot of good things though so I decided to go back and had much better experiences going forward. I usually order the texas two step and I love it. They have great cold brew coffee, bloody mary's and other brunch drinks. After 10:30am they start getting pretty busy so I would recommend making a reservation if you want to go later.

Went there for brunch and had the blueberry and bacon flap jacks. They were huge, the size of my whole plate. Very tasty. Those flat jacks and the syrup gave me a sugar rush and I later crashed out for a nap. A nice afternoon in my book.

Visited Eldoarado during Restaurant Week and I was surprisingly pleased. I am not usually a fan of Tex-Mex, but their restaurant week menu was appealing to me so I gave it a try. I started off with some chips and salsa (you can get complimentary chips and salsa if you check in through yelp). The chips come in a pretty large basket, so be careful and leave room for dinner! I tired a cup of their pozole soup and it was fine, but I've had better. For my entree I ordered the salmon which came with a pomegranate BBQ glaze, mashed potatoes, and brussel sprouts. This entree was AMAZING! I loved everything about this dish. The salmon was perfectly cooked, the mashed potatoes were velvety and smooth, and the brussels had a slight crunch. I was going to to return for this exact dish, but It seems that this entree is not on their regular menu so I am super bummed out about that. For my dessert, I had the Chocolate Ancho Pecan Pie and this was tasty too. I want to return and try their Texas Torpedos. A couple next to me ordered those and they looked delicious. I hope I'm wrong about the Salmon, but I still look forward to stopping by again in the near future.

We stopped at opening time on a Saturday for a few drinks and some Chips and Salsa and Guacamole before dinner at another restaurant, since we'd read rave reviews about Eldorado's margaritas.  We found the staff to be decidedly and unusually unfriendly, compared to most restaurants and bars in the area, although the female Bartender was a serious and excellent Mixologist.  Our two favorite Margaritas were the Honey-Ginger & the Eldorado Margarita, although the Mango and Raspberry Margaritas were also interesting, and much fresher and real, and not cloyingly sweet at all. The Chips were fresh, and the Salsa was much more distinctive than the Guacamole, so if you can handle a Heavy dose of disdain from the staff along with your Cocktails, and Chips, you may enjoy a trip to Eldorado.

Went here for the first time Friday after driving past it over the years. It's actually quite tasty. Had the quinoa stuffed poblano and a regular margarita on the rocks. I'm glad there were a few vegan items to choose from, again this is one of those places where you can't take out ingredients because certain things are pre-prepared. Which can leave you with more limited choices on the menu. The guac was so delicious. Everyone in our party loved what they ordered to eat. I thought the poblano was so smokey, it made the table smell like camp fire. I also asked for hot sauce, because I like my food hotter than the sun, it was kind of the the person caring for our table to say they made their own and to be careful because it was really really hot...I honestly thought it could have been hotter.  I would definitely rec this place and go here again.

We stopped in Madison on our way back home to Chicago What a treat the salsa is made fresh everyday and it's Amazon For those who are gluten free the chips are fried in dedicated friers so they are safe to eat and are thin and crispy The blackened catfish was very flavorful Dare you to try to have just one  margarita They were soo good that we had the second one ordered before we finished the first ones Eat at the Eldorado!
We've been here twice, the last time being two weeks ago.  I had the Machaca Pork Burrito.  Tasty as heck.  The service is very friendly and prompt.  Love it.  We'll be back for sure.

Margaritas were great, as usual. Service was sub par. Hostess seemed awkward and disinterested. Our server was OK, but a little too terse and didn't smile much. Bartender seemed irritated to be there, didn't say anything when he approached the table with our drinks and didn't smile. He did say thank you when we left.

the ginger margarita is amazing. had the salmon and shrimp with pear jicama salsa which was super delicious. the shrimp were slightly overcooked so a little tough but the flavor was still good. Also loved the asparagus.

Went here for brunch with some ladies this past Sunday.   I know for dinner this place is definately overpriced for what you get but for brunch, it ws definately reasonably priced for brunch, with most items around $8.   It was packed when we got there but we only had to wait about 10 minutes.  We went to the bar and got two bloodys and a coffee.  We got the one with the house-made chili infused vodka and it came with an amber beer chaser, for $6.50. When we got seated we waited, no lie, about 10 minutes before we were approached by a server.  I was just about to go to the host stand when a frazzled server stopped by.  We placed our order and waited, again, for about 30 min to get our food.  I work in the service industry and not even dinner items take 30 minutes... Whatever. The food was good though and almost made up for the wait.  I originally wanted the mango-pineapple french toast, but they were out of the mango :( so I had the banana walnut french toast... it was really good, and they coat the bread in some type of crunchy crumbs before they grill them! My friends both got the crab eggs benedict and they loved it!  At the end of the meal, we had to wait another 15 minutes to get the bill paid and get a box.  If it wasn't for the shoddy service I wouldv'e given this place 4 stars.

I've always thought the food here was good, but I was completely wowed during a recent brunch experience. The hit the trail pancakes are absolutely delicious and you must order one as a side even if you order other entrees. I've never had anything like it. It's a dense pancake, perfectly griddled, and includes seeds and nuts. The butter has a little Southwest kick to it, too!  My husband and I both had wonderful egg dishes and shared a pancake. The service was excellent.  They take reservations, which are highly recommended. We didn't know this, but were seated right away on the heated patio, which is first come, first served. The bar is also open seating.  This is definitely a brunch hot spot for Madison, with unique flavors and a great atmosphere and service.
I was a little disappointed with Eldorado Grill but definitely plan on going back to give it another chance because it had potential.
Best brunch I have ever had. Omelets are absolutely fantastic, as are the breakfast burritos and bloody Mary's!

Eldorado is the place to go for happy hour! They have half priced appetizers ($3.50-$4.50) and they all are delicious. I recommend trying the tamales & fish cakes. During happy hour the chips & salsa are $0.90 and they're wonderful. Happy hour margaritas are $6. I really like the "World Famous Margarita", it's lime on the rocks...and will knock off your socks. On Mondays they have all day happy hour. I've also been here for brunch, everyone enjoyed what they ordered. They have a great variety on their brunch menu; a nice balance between sweet & savory. There can be a long wait for brunch, if you have a big group you may want to get a reservation. I've also had Eldorado cater a graduation party that I planned, all the guests LOVED the food. People raved about the catered potato salad & pulled pork sandwiches. If you love Mexican food you must try Eldorado Grill.

I've tried this place on a number of occasions and have never left feeling like I want to go back. (however some of my friends do, so back I go) Their tequila selection is amazing, I'd recommend it for drinks. The food has varied for me from not okay to bad. Go for Happy Hour, then go somewhere else for dinner.

Great brunch.  Wonderful selection and the food is fresh.  I have tried multiple dishes and am almost always enthralled.  Wonderful Bloody Mary's and their chips/salsa is fabulous.  I always get a side of their house salsa to eat with my food.  Staff is always friendly and helpful.  One time we had to wait a very long time for our food and didn't say anything, but our waitress apologize regardless and gave us free drink coupons.  Definitely recommend making reservations for brunch or on a weekend night.  The wait can long otherwise.
Great atmosphere, prompt service, delicious food. Love to go for brunch or for dinner in the winter.

Came here for restaurant week and LOVED it! The salmon was perfectly cooked (I'm pretty snobby about that), and the sweet potatoes and brussel sprouts complemented the fish well. That, with the street tacos (definitely try the fried avocado ones!) and dessert were well worth the $25.

I was visiting in Madison this past weekend, and we went to Eldorado for brunch. What a great experience. We started with Bloody Mary's with a small beer chaser. For entrees, we had the Eggs Benedict with salmon, French Toast, and the street tacos. Everything was excellent. We also had a good server. The place was crowded, but the staff didn't seem to have any problems, either out front or in the kitchen.

I've been to Eldorado Grill four times now - once during Madison's restaurant week, once for Happy Hour, once for brunch, and once (most recently) for dinner. All four times, I've come away thinking that I should have started eating here MUCH sooner (something I kick myself about now that I've moved out of Madison).  Some favorites from the menu:  -EVERY SINGLE MARGARITA I'VE TRIED. Seriously, folks. These margaritas are just killer. The fruit purees make for a really tasty, fresh drink. The honey-ginger margarita is a unique drink that warms you up from the inside out. The standard margaritas are fresh and smooth. It's all just. so. GOOD.  -Texas Torpedoes. While they give you a bigger kick than you'd expect for only using jalapenos, this appetizer is one that shouldn't be missed at any time of day or night.  -BBQ Glazed Salmon. This was a surprisingly awesome dish. It was a bit more traditional than what you'd expect from a funky Tex-Mex place like Eldorado Grill, but I don't even care because I'm still dreaming about that perfect bite of salmon, chutney, garlic mashed potatoes, and brussels sprouts. I can't wait to go back so I can taste it again.  -Eldorado Benedict. I'm a benedict fan, and this one doesn't disappoint. The fact that you get a not-insubstantial piece of salmon along with two potato pancakes and poached eggs... Man oh man, that was the best breakfast I've had in a loooong time. Highly recommend.  Honestly, though, I haven't had anything here that I disliked. The one menu option that didn't meet expectations was the Vegan Chorizo/Vegetable Stuffed Poblano, which, while tasty, didn't have much flavor coming from the chorizo itself. I've had my fair share of non-vegan chorizo and missed its distinctive flavor here. However, the poblano itself had a delicious smoky flavor - one you don't often get from meat-free entrees.  If you're in Madison and wanting a place to check out for dinner, Eldorado Grill does not disappoint.

Ok the first Cadillac margarita was good, the second was SO limey we sent it back!  The food, well the enchiladas were pretty good, fried more like flautas  then enchiladas, but good.  The pork tenderloin was SO over-cooked.  It was take a bite of pork, add a swallow of water, chew and swallow.  It was BAD!  I know this is in a hip hood, but there were definitely very good items and REALLY bad ones.  Mixed bag!  It is nothing like traditional Mexican, it's a take off on Mexican.  I'd recommended the enchiladas, stay far, far a way from pork.  We should have sent it back for the price.
